p: G. lamblia is an enteric protozoan parasite that causes endemic enteric infections of human and animal clinical importance. It is one of the most common causes of enteric infections in children and in farm and domestic animals (dogs and cats) and is mainly associated with poor sanitary conditions and zoonotic transmission ( 150). Giardiasis is a common cause of waterborne outbreaks of diarrhea due to the transmission of Giardia cysts. It is a zoonotic disease. Clinical manifestations of giardiasis include diarrhea, loss of weight, anorexia, and lethargy, both in humans and animals. Currently, there is no human-licensed vaccine against giardiasis, but a crude veterinary vaccine composed of the total lysate of Giardia lamblia trophozoites, called GiardiaVaxÂ® ( Table 1), was licensed as a preventive tool ( 151). It was shown to attenuate giardiasis symptoms and to prevent cysts spreading in cats and dogs ( 151) but not in calves ( 152).
